reviewText: A gentile series about a small town lawyer in coastal England. It's a role for Stephen Fry that one would not have expected given his past roles, like Black Adder and Jeeves and Wooster. It's most enjoyable!

reviewText: Down home charm and folksy wisdom OR unrelenting eccentricity and cloying sentimentality?  That is a divide that you may face when exploring the British series "Kingdom."  Another show that posits that any life spent in the big city rat race is a wasted one, "Kingdom" may certainly connect with your heart more than your brain.  And that's OK.  It is certainly not the first show to explore small town wackiness (Gilmore Girls, Northern Exposure to name a couple) and it most definitely won't be the last.  But these shows can work as prime examples of escapism with their gentle humor and offbeat sensibilities.  So if you're looking for something to fill that niche, the world inhabited by Peter Kingdom is a pretty pleasant place to visit. Of course, I'd probably be happy watching Stephen Fry in just about anything!  So maybe I'm biased.  In a strange turn of events, Season Two of "Kingdom" actually had a North American DVD debut prior to the release of Season One.  That's no way to start watching a series and, for my money, these initial six episodes from 2007 are the series' strongest (also, they set up the entire premise).As I mentioned, the great Fry is Peter Kingdom who uproots his life to take residence in a picturesque village in Norfolk.  Becoming a country solicitor was not something he envisioned, but when his brother goes missing--the mystery becomes a priority.  Some of these early moments have a refreshing darkness and danger due to the uncertainty of his unknown fate.  This side plot, in my opinion, is one of the best aspects in Season One (and I missed it moving into later seasons, but I digress).  Amidst this personal story, though, Fry has hung his shingle, taken on an appropriately wacky sidekick and colorful associates, and is working for the local common folk.  A typical episode will start with an amusing kicker and end with a sweet resolution with little variation to this expected formula.  I might have hoped that the show would take more risks or stray from its conventional storytelling routine, but part of the program's appeal is its comfort factor.  "Kingdom" seeks to be lighthearted (and big hearted) entertainment, and I went along for the ride.Within these first six episodes (approximately 45 minutes each without commercials, presented over 2 DVDs), Fry contends with unruly neighbors, unsympathetic insurance companies, pompous bureaucrats, combating spouses, and dismissive governing boards.  His clients are always the underdog, and Fry and team are always the champion.  It doesn't take a lot of imagination to see how most of these cases will end up triumphant.  But it's more about the journey than the destination.  And most of the shows are pleasant and amusing, if not particularly beleivable, and there's nothing wrong with that.  I genuinely enjoyed "Kingdom" in spite of certain intellectual reservations.  Season One is fitfully entertaining, provides some panoramic scenery, and introduces enough skewed characters to populate several shows. It's always good to see Fry and here he has a game cast willing to fully embrace the eccentricities of any scenario.  The DVD release also has a Behind the Scenes documentary that can be appreciated by fans.  KGHarris, 10/12.
summary: Small Town Eccentricity And Whimsy Rule The Law In This Endearing British Dramedy

reviewText: Reasonably well done production about a village solicitor and the antics he, his family and staff get into. Set in a marvelous seaside village which serves as a backdrop for the series. Average dialog and acting. More like, but not as good as Doc Martin. Not in the same class as Mapp and Lucia or All Creatures, though. An Easy going series making it easy to watch and easy to take.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The spouse and I recently finished watching Doc Martin through Season 5.  I in particular found myself going through serious withdrawal.  Kingdom is a pretty great antidote.  Better than DM in some ways.  Stephen Fry as Peter Kingdom is dry, real, and remarkably free of quirks.  There's a backstory there which unfolds at a leisurely pace.  The setting owes more than a little to Doc Martin's Port Isaac - is there a whole subgenre of professional types escaping the big city and returning to the quirky English village?  At any rate, Market Shipborough is quite scenic and also most satisfactorily populated by a plethora of wacky but adorable citizens.  Then there are a couple who are not quite so wacky - Peter's secretary Gloria, and his indomitable Aunt Auriel.  The young assistant Lyle seems to be evolving from wet behind the ears to cocky and annoying, but Peter is pretty unflappable and has him under control.  Peter's sister Beatrice, definitely a catastrophe waiting to happen.  It's pure entertainment and we are really enjoying it.  Definitely recommended, especially if you enjoy Doc Martin, All Creatures, and other series of that ilk (there must be others!)
Title: N/A
